webTitle: Inflation drops to 2.8% as oil prices slide

fields.standfirst: Goverment figures shows annual inflation rate, measured on consumer price index, slipped to 2.8% in May from 3% in April
fields.body:
Inflation has slipped to its lowest level in two and a half years, in a rare piece of good news for Britain's recession-hit households.

The Office for National Statistics said the annual inflation rate, measured on the consumer price index, slipped to 2.8% last month from 3% in April, as falling oil prices fed through to cheaper petrol at the pump.

The ONS cited motor fuels as the biggest factor, with petrol prices falling by 4.5p a litre in a single month, to stand at £1.37.

During May, the cost of a barrel of Brent crude oil on international markets slipped from $120 to $103. It has since fallen further, to $83.

On the retail price index measure, which also includes housing costs, inflation slipped to 3.1% in May from 3.5% a month earlier.

Though inflation is still well above the Bank of England's target of 2%, the fall should help to reassure policymakers that they can take more action to stimulate the economy without sparking a renewed surge in prices.

The Bank of England governor, Sir Mervyn King, hinted in his Mansion House speech last week that the monetary policy committee could unleash a fresh bout of quantitative easing - electronic money creation - alongside the government's new measures for kickstarting credit.

Jeremy Cook, of the currency broker World First, said the data "will trigger a sigh of relief from Threadneedle St" as it gives the Bank further leeway with possible further expansionary monetary policy, such as interest rate cuts or additional asset purchases.

Some members of the Bank's monetary policy committee (MPC) have previously expressed caution about more QE, warning that it could push up inflation, but world commodity prices have been falling in recent weeks amid fears about a slowdown in the world economy. Wednesday's minutes from the MPC's June meeting will show whether any members were calling for more QE.

The ONS said food and non-alcoholic drink prices rose by 0.3% between April and May, compared with a 1.3% increase a year ago, meaning that food prices also contributed to the downward slide in inflation.

webTitle: Weir shares jump after it unveils "punchy" growth targets for its minerals business

fields.standfirst: Company expects to double division's operating profits by 2016 as revenues climb
fields.body:
Weir is one of the best performers of the day so far, as the pumps and valves group gives an upbeat assessment of its minerals business.

Ahead of a presentation in the City, the company said it had won equipment orders worth £1.1bn in the division since January 2010, which was likely to give additional aftermarket revenues of up to £3bn in the next ten to 15 years. This should help the division double last year's operating profits by 2016.

More immediately it confirmed its full year guidance for 2012. Oriel Securities analyst Harry Phillips told Reuters:

They've put in a very punchy growth target for their minerals business which is in our view, more than just a reiteration of guidance for the current year, it's a surprisingly up-tempo target they've set.

So Weir's shares have jumped 70p to £15.07, making it the second biggest riser in the FTSE 100 behind Whitbread, which has been boosted by a positive trading update.

But Unilever is leading the FTSE fallers, down 45p at £20.42 after French food group Danone warned it had cut its 2012 margin target due to the worsening economic conditions in southern Europe, Spain in particular.

webTitle: Home Retail gains 16% after better than expected performance from Argos

fields.standfirst: Group says Argos made a solid start but Homebase seasonal sales were hit by poor weather
fields.body:
As markets edged higher ahead of the latest Spanish debt auction and hopes of action to stimulate the US economy from the Federal Reserve, a couple of UK consumer companies were leading the way.

Whitbread jumped 131p to £19.80, leading the FTSE 100 after an upbeat trading statement.

Perhaps more surprisingly, Home Retail is the best performer in the mid-cap index, up 11.65p to 86p, a near 16% increase. The Argos and Homebase owner after it turned in a better than expected performance in the first quarter.

Argos saw like for like sales dip 0.2% but this was well above forecasts of a 3% decline. Meanwhile Homebase dropped 8.3%, in line with expectations, and also said gross margins had improved by 225 basis points. The company has suffered in the current environment with its low income customers in particular hit by the squeeze on earnings. It is also suffering competition from supermarkets and online retailers including Amazon. But chief executive Terry Duddy said:

Over a particularly volatile trading period Argos had a solid start to the year supported by its multi-channel performance, while at Homebase the poor weather conditions adversely impacted seasonal product sales.

The "multi-channel" strategy led many analysts to suggest it needed a major store closing programme at Argos, and the company has said it plans to shut around 10 stores this year. It expects to meet market expectations for the full year, with the concensus around £67m of pretax profit.

JP Morgan Cazenove put an overweight rating on the shares, saying:

The stock has fallen by 11% in the year to date, underperforming the sector by almost 20% and is now trading on 10.5 times 2012's PE on our above consensus estimates. Given the weather year to date, this morning's update is much better than expected, especially at Argos, which delivered a strong performance in consumer electronics. Home remains a stock where opinion on the potential is strongly divided. The valuation falls significantly to 7.5 times next year as we assume the group realises significant operational gearing benefits. Given the still high short base in the stock and this morning's better performance, it would seem reasonable to expect the shares to squeeze today.

But Philip Dorgan at Panmure Gordon said:

We remain negative, because we believe that Argos has too many stores, too high a fixed cost base and is close to making losses. It is difficult to see a value creating solution to its problems, which is why we remain sellers of Home Retail, with a sum of the parts-based target price of 51p.

David Jeary at Investec also issued a sell note, but saw some encouraging signs:

We remain negative on the fundamentals in light of our view of structural pressures magnifying the cyclical pressures, especially on the core Argos division.
This said, the more positive performance from the electricals category has moved the chain within a whisker of what we have always seen as a key catalyst for the group – namely the return of Argos to positive like for like sales. We will review our investment case when we have seen the outturn of the second quarter and can gauge whether the first quarter performance was a flash in the pan or a potential turning point.

The company was also in focus ahead of the update following weekend reports of possible private equity interest in Argos.

Overall the FTSE 100 has added 31.54 points to 5522.63, but investors are still nervous about the eurozone crisis, as the G20 meeting continues in Mexico and ahead of a number of bond auctions and worries about the Spanish banking system.

This said, the more positive performance from the electricals category has moved the chain within a whisker of what we have always seen as a key catalyst for the group – namely the return of Argos to positive like for like sales. We will review our investment case when we have seen the outturn of the second quarter and can gauge whether the first quarter performance was a flash in the pan or a potential turning point. The company was also in focus ahead of the update following weekend reports of possible private equity interest in Argos. Overall the FTSE 100 has added 31.54 points to 5522.63, but investors are still nervous about the eurozone crisis, as the G20 meeting continues in Mexico and ahead of a number of bond auctions and worries about the Spanish banking system.
